Posts.Title: Editorial: Bad Prostate Cancer Advice

Posts.Content: There is no good food. Period. Just recently saw a paper that vitamins and supplements help cancer to spread. http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releas...-ssa101315.php Carbs are very bad because they chemically react with your own proteins and cause a lot of damage. Plus they are converted to fat in your liver. Believe or not, fat is not as bad as carbs and if you cut on carbs substantially you need to replace them with fat and protein. I eat low carb veggies, fish, chicken, eggs and not much fruit. Is organic red meat OK? BTW, it's much easier to do a study on one compound that on hundreds if not thousands compounds in foods. I cannot imagine how to do it scientifically.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind At this point, perhaps his primary doctor, the one directing his treatment, should be a Medical Oncologist not a Urologist....There are new, advanced drugs and treatments but they are very expensive and can be hard to get access to..A non prescription supplement, Pomi-T, has shown it can slow down the cancer progression somewhat..It's cheap and can't hurt..... I disagree. It can hurt. Antioxidants and supplements interfere with killing cancer cells. They help them survive.

Posts.Content: I think the difference is just the amount of the drug in one tablet. It's the same product. If you take a 100 mg pill of viagra, then you will need 5 pills of Revatio to have the same effect. Actually, I read that the sildenafil was first discovered for blood hypertension, and some patients reported the other effect.

Posts.Title: Difference Between Viagra and Revatio (Both sildenafil citrate tablets from Pfizer)

Posts.Content: There is this study that looked into frequency of second specific primary cancers (SPCs). http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/1.../cam4.116/full There is an interesting chart there. The three most common SPCs after the prostate cancer were colorectal, bladder, and lung cancers. Check your bladders and gut PC folks.

Posts.Content: Ron, ask your uro to check your bladder from time to time. Bladder cancer was the #1 second primery cancer in total. I have it after I have been with lymphoma for 23 years.

Posts.Title: The incidence of second primary cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Without drilling down to compare treatment modalities, the study is not very helpful to us prostate cancer patients. There are numerous studies within the prostate cancer treatment communities on comparing secondary cancer risk from various treatment methods. The findings (I can go back and dig those studies out if someone is interested) I remembered when I was searching for treatment options were: 1. For surgery, colorectal and bladder cancer risks were no different from the general population. 2. For brachy, the colorectal and bladder cancer risks were only slightly higher than the general population. 3. For external beam radiation, they about double the risk of the general population, but if you looked at the absolute number, i.e., case per 100,000, it was still a very small number and comparable to the risk of death/complications due to surgery. But remember, the outcome for radiation was taken over a long time (years if not decades) and the technology in external radiation has improved so much that I am sure the risks are much smaller nowadays. And, I think that was the reason many doctors recommended surgery for very young prostate cancer patients as they still have decades to live and cancer risk due to radiation goes up in time after treatment. So, it is correct that we should watch out for the possibility of secondary cancer, it is not a risk high enough that those needing treatment should stop getting treatment. Specifically, those that were treated with external radiation should not lose any sleep. Others should perhaps just follow the guidelines for the general population. Peace, just want to add my comments and not try to create a fight. As I understood this paper, it's not about your treatments that cause a second cancer, it's about the common mutations that drive a primary cancer and a second primary cancer. They can be concurrent or one after another. And each of the cancers should be treated as best as possible.
